subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: So said  Mike Colbert   on  12/14/2002 ...  ... Certainly not. That s simple enough not to break on its own 99.9% percent of the
messageBody:
So said Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@...> on 12/14/2002
--------------------

<snip />
>> Based on the above description, I disagree that you practice TDD. If
>> you practiced TDD, then you would not write, "...likely I also
>needed
>> to add something to the corresponding test code." If you practiced
>TDD,
>> you would:
>>
>> 1. Write a test
>> 2. Watch it fail
>> 3. Make it pass
>> 4. Refactor
>
>Consider it's a value object, and I simply need to add a property,
>along with a getter and setter. I don't write tests for that
>everytime. (We have a BaseTestCase with a checkProperties() method
>that automatically does this for us via introspection.)

Certainly not. That's simple enough not to break on its own 99.9%
percent of the time... Can we match this back to the question?

>> It's the last step that leads you to see that your TestCase is doing
>> too much is a candidate to be factored into smaller objects.
>>
>> I have worked on a project where test cases quickly became
>difficult to
>> understand because of the massive amount of test setup -- mostly
>> priming a database with known data. None of our attempts to solve
>the
>> problem were entirely satisfying and the team did not agree to let
>me
>> test the business logic entirely separately from the persistence
>> mechanism. The result was this: after not seeing a certain TestCase
>for
>> a few days it would take 10 minutes or so to remember or re-
>understand
>> what was going on. Also, changes to the test setup had cascading
>> effects on the rest of the tests. If I had just created a new
>TestCase,
>> I could have factored the real commonality up and kept the details
>> separate. That would certainly have helped, and this explains why I
>> have adopted that technique as a habit.
>
>I have a similar problem on my current project. I'm writing a
>persistence layer. Loosely speaking, my tests take an object graph,
>persist it, read it from the persistence layer, and validate it's
>structure. The important thing is, and this is where we share a
>common problem, there is a lot of setup involved. In my case, to
>construct an object graph everytime a test is run. My approach was
>to create a seperate class (named DAOTestFixture, of all things)
>which constructs and contains the object graph. I simply create an
>instance of this class from the setUp() method in all my DAO
>TestCases. At this point, I have about eight DAOs and corresponding
>TestCases that reuse this test fixture. Plus, I get to use inner
>classes, reap all the benefits, and there is nothing to stop me from
>refactoring those TestCases into seperate inner classes should I want
>to in the future. If I ever find I need to share a TestCase across
>classes (would this ever happen?), I suppose I could refactor it into
>it's own freestanding class.

So you compose text fixtures, rather than extending them. There's no
law that says a TestCase must descend from a fixture or implement the
fixture itself, but from an organizational standpoint it is nicer for
the reader if each TestCase were a separate fixture, as long as the
fixture is not tiny.

It's like anything else: if you roll up three tiny things into one big
thing, that may be no problem; but if you roll up three big things into
one even bigger thing, bad things tend to happen.

>> >Now, based on those very simple real world requirements, just
>exactly
>> >what is it that makes your approach so superior that you will
>> >immediately discount all others as inadequate?
>>
>> At this point, I feel that you are being unnecessarily antagonistic.
>> Rudeness objection. Please tone it down.
>
>Oh, but it's my approach that was attacked with a groundless claim.
>Sorry for wondering why.

I will not stop you from wondering why, but I can ask you to act less
like an ass when you point out that you don't agree. This might work:

"Now, based on those very simple real-world requirements, it looks like
my approach does the job. What is there in your approach that I am
missing with mine?"

It may be that Dave was describing a general-purpose, one-size-fits-all
approach that could be optimized in your specific case. If you ask him
civilly, I'm sure he'll respond. If you feel he was being uncivil
towards you, then be the bigger man and tell him so, civilly. I missed
his part of the exchange, so I can't say.

>> >I know, I know, it's in the newsletter and the forthcoming book.
>> >That's fabulous. But you're preaching to the TDD converted here
>and
>> >we have found our own ways, based first on the information
>currently
>> >available and second on our own experience.
>> <snip />
>>
>> Given that your above statement (way up there) indicates that you do
>> not practice TDD, but rather that you do something else that is
>> somewhere similar to TDD, I am not sure that you can directly use
>your
>> experience to argue either in favor or against TDD. I apologize if
>that
>> is harsh, but I believe it is objectively true. I make no value
>> judgement: do what you do if it works, but please do not call it
>TDD.
>
>I don't see how you could have ever concluded that I don't do TDD
>based on my statment above. Definitely a stretch ...

Well, you didn't argue against it in your reply after the part in which
I wrote it, so I assumed that you at least didn't violently disagree.
If you write code first, then "likely" add tests, why is that TDD? I
don't think it is.
